name: Alan Turing
contribution: Alan Turing was highly influential in the development of theoretical computer science. He formalised the concepts of algorithm and computation with the Turing machine, which serves as a model for general-purpose computers. He also worked on German naval cryptanalysis during World War II, speeding up the breaking of German ciphers, including improvements to the pre-war Polish bomba method. Post-war, he designed the Automatic Computing Engine, one of the first designs for a stored-program computer. He further developed the Manchester computers and wrote on the chemical basis of morphogenesis.
importance: Turing is considered the father of theoretical computer science and his work in cryptanalysis during WW II played a crucial role in defeating the Axis powers in many critical engagements, including the Battle of the Atlantic. He left an extensive legacy in mathematics and computing. Turing's work is recognised widely today, with many things named after him, including an annual award for computing innovation. His portrait appears on the Bank of England £50 note.
politicalInfluence: Turing was prosecuted for homosexual acts in 1952 and accepted hormone treatment, a form of chemical castration, as an alternative to prison. His treatment led to an official public apology by British Prime minister Gordon Brown in 2009. Queen Elizabeth II granted a pardon in 2013. The 'Alan Turing law' is an informal term for a 2017 UK law that retroactively pardoned men cautioned or convicted under historical legislation that outlawed homosexual acts.

name: Grace Hopper
contribution: Grace Hopper was a pioneer of computer programming and was the first to devise the theory of machine-independent programming languages. She used this theory to develop the FLOW-MATIC programming language and COBOL, an early high-level programming language still in use today. She was also one of the first programmers on the Harvard Mark I computer and is credited with writing the first computer manual, 'A Manual of Operation for the Automatic Sequence Controlled Calculator.'
importance: Hopper played a significant role in the development of modern computer languages. Her work paved the way for using English-based language in code, making programming more accessible. She was instrumental in the creation of COBOL, which is still in use today and served as the foundation for many modern programming languages. Her belief that programming should be simplified with an English-based computer programming language led her to develop compilers that could convert English terms into machine code understood by computers.
politicalInfluence: Hopper's influence extended to the United States Navy, where she reached the rank of rear admiral. The U.S. Navy named a guided-missile destroyer, the USS Hopper, in her honor. Additionally, a supercomputer and a GPU architecture bear her name, signaling her impact and influence in the field of computing technology.

name: Donald Knuth
contribution: Donald Knuth is the author of multi-volume work The Art of Computer Programming and he contributed to the development of rigorous analysis of the computational complexity of algorithms and systematized formal mathematical techniques for it. He has popularized the asymptotic notation. He has also made contributions in several branches of theoretical computer science. He is the creator of the TeX computer typesetting system, the related METAFONT font definition language and rendering system, and the Computer Modern family of typefaces. Knuth also created the WEB and CWEB computer programming systems designed to encourage and facilitate literate programming, and designed the MIX/MMIX instruction set architectures.
importance: Donald Knuth is a prominent figure in the field of computer science, often called the 'father of the analysis of algorithms'. He is the recipient of the 1974 ACM Turing Award, which is informally considered the Nobel Prize of computer science. His work on algorithm analysis, computer typesetting systems, and his contributions to theoretical computer science have significantly shaped the discipline.
politicalInfluence: Knuth strongly opposes the granting of software patents. He has expressed his opinion to the United States Patent and Trademark Office and European Patent Organisation.

name: Ada Lovelace
contribution: Ada Lovelace is chiefly known for her work on Charles Babbage's proposed mechanical general-purpose computer, the Analytical Engine. She was the first to recognise that the machine had applications beyond pure calculation. Between 1842 and 1843, Lovelace translated an article about the Analytical Engine, supplementing it with an elaborate set of seven notes, simply called 'Notes'. Lovelace's notes are important in the early history of computers, especially the seventh one which contained what many consider to be the first computer program—that is, an algorithm designed to be carried out by a machine. Lovelace also developed a vision of the capability of computers to go beyond mere calculating or number-crunching. The programming language Ada is named after her.
importance: Ada Lovelace's work on Charles Babbage's proposed mechanical general-purpose computer, the Analytical Engine, is considered significantly influential in the field of computer science. She was the first to realise and propose that such machines had applications beyond pure calculation, and her 'Notes' that accompanied her translation of an article about the Analytical Engine form an important part in computer history. They contain what is considered by many to be the first computer program. Lovelace's vision of the capacity of computers to go beyond mere calculation was remarkable at a time when many, including Babbage, focused only on these capabilities.
politicalInfluence: Regarded as the first computer programmer, Lovelace’s foresight about the potential of computing inspired the recognition of computing as more than mere calculation. Her legacy has influenced movements for gender diversity in STEM, as well as policies emphasizing ethical and interdisciplinary approaches to technology development.

name: Edsger W. Dijkstra
contribution: Edsger W. Dijkstra was a computer scientist, programmer, software engineer, and mathematician. He formulated and solved the shortest path problem and developed the first compiler for the programming language ALGOL 60. He also built the THE multiprogramming system, and wrote nearly 500 documents in research articles, most of them technical reports. Additionally, Dijkstra has made fundamental contributions to developing structured programming languages and made a significant impact on self-stabilization of program computation.
importance: Edsger W. Dijkstra's contributions to computer science have been fundamental and varied. His work in formulating the shortest path problem and developing the first compiler for the programming language ALGOL 60 set the stage for subsequent advancements in these areas. His creation of the THE multiprogramming system influenced the designs of subsequent systems by introducing the concept of software-based paged virtual memory. His extensive research and technical reports have also been instrumental to the field. His contribution to structured programming languages and self-stabilization of program computation has won him prestigious awards such as the Turing Award and the ACM PODC Influential Paper Award. His annual award was later renamed the Dijkstra Prize in his honor.
politicalInfluence: Dijkstra was instrumental in promoting the importance of formal methods, algorithmic rigor, and structured programming. His famous “Go To Statement Considered Harmful” paper influenced software development policies and educational curricula, steering the field away from chaotic coding practices. His ideas indirectly influenced software engineering governance.

name: Claude Shannon
contribution: Shannon was the first to describe the Boolean gates that are essential to all digital electronic circuits, and was one of the founding fathers of artificial intelligence. His master's thesis established the theory behind digital computing and digital circuits. He also contributed to the field of cryptanalysis, including fundamental work on codebreaking and secure telecommunications. His mathematical theory of communication laid the foundations for the field of information theory. He formally introduced the term 'bit', and made various contributions to the field of artificial intelligence, including programming a computer for chess.
importance: Shannon is known as 'the father of information theory' and 'the father of the Information Age'. His work in Boolean gates, AI, cryptography, and information theory is fundamental to the digital revolution, and is widely used in various scientific endeavors such as the development of the Internet and mobile phones. His work is regarded as one of the greatest intellectual achievements of the twentieth century, on par with those of Albert Einstein, Sir Isaac Newton, and Charles Darwin.
politicalInfluence: Known as the father of information theory, Shannon’s work laid the foundation for digital communication and encryption. His theories influenced cybersecurity policies, cryptography, and the development of communication standards that are integral to modern governance and defense systems.

name: Linus Torvalds
contribution: Linus Benedict Torvalds is the creator and lead developer of the Linux kernel. He also created the distributed version control system Git. He was honored with the 2012 Millennium Technology Prize by the Technology Academy Finland for his creation of a new open source operating system for computers leading to the widely used Linux kernel. He is also the recipient of the 2014 IEEE Computer Society Computer Pioneer Award and the 2018 IEEE Masaru Ibuka Consumer Electronics Award.
importance: Torvalds' work on the Linux kernel and Git has significantly contributed to the field of computer science. The Linux kernel is extensively used to power servers, desktops, Android phones, and more, making it a critical component of much of the world's software infrastructure. Similarly, Git has become the de-facto standard for version control in software development, enabling teams of developers to collaborate on code.
politicalInfluence: Torvalds created Linux, the open-source operating system that has become a backbone of modern computing. His leadership in the open-source movement has had significant political and economic implications, promoting software freedom and decentralization. He indirectly influenced policies around intellectual property and open-source software adoption in governments and industries.

name: Dennis Ritchie
contribution: Dennis Ritchie created the C programming language and, along with Ken Thompson, developed the Unix operating system and B language. Throughout his career, he also contributed to other systems including Plan 9, Inferno, and the programming language Limbo. Furthermore, he co-wrote the book The C Programming Language with Brian Kernighan.
importance: Ritchie's work was foundational to Computer Science. His creation of the C programming language influenced several other languages such as C++, Objective-C used by Apple, C# used by Microsoft, and Java extensively used in corporate environments and by Android. Together with Ken Thompson, they used C to write Unix, which established many computing concepts and principles that are extensively adopted. Ritchie's Unix and C programming language also led to huge advances in computer hardware, software, and networking systems.
politicalInfluence: Co-creator of C and Unix, Ritchie’s work has had a lasting impact on operating systems and software standards. Unix inspired the development of POSIX standards, which have guided governmental and organizational decisions regarding system interoperability and standardization.

name: Bjarne Stroustrup
contribution: Known for the development of the C++ programming language. Led the Large-scale Programming Research department at Bell Labs, served as a professor of computer science at Texas A&M University, and spent over a decade at Morgan Stanley while also being a visiting professor at Columbia University. Currently, he is a full professor at Columbia University.
importance: Stroustrup's work on the C++ programming language has significantly influenced the field of computer science. He conceived, formulated and implemented many of its key features, setting design criteria and processing extension proposals. His work laid the foundations for the language, making it one of the most influential in the history of computing.
politicalInfluence: Stroustrup created C++, a language foundational to systems programming. His work influenced industry policies around the development of high-performance and scalable software, impacting domains such as defense, finance, and telecommunications.

name: Guido van Rossum
contribution: Creator of the Python programming language, contributor of glob() routine to BSD Unix, helped develop the ABC programming language, created Grail, an early web browser written in Python. He also worked for various tech companies including Google, Dropbox and Microsoft, and contributed in developing Python language, Mondrian (a web-based code review system), and a custom programming language for Elemental Security.
importance: Guido van Rossum's creation, Python, is one of the most popular languages used in computer science. It is an open source language, which means anyone can contribute to its evolution. It became the second most popular language on GitHub in 2019. It has remained among the 10 most popular programming languages since 2004 and got the number one spot on the TIOBE Programming Community Index in October 2021. Guido van Rossum's work on Python earned him several awards in the field of computer science.
politicalInfluence: As the creator of Python, van Rossum shaped programming education and accessibility. Python’s role in data science, artificial intelligence, and government research initiatives has made it a key player in technology policy and scientific funding decisions.

name: Larry Page
contribution: Co-founding Google, serving as the chief executive officer of Google from 1997 until August 2001 and again from April 2011 until July 2015, and becoming the CEO of Alphabet Inc. He is also the co-creator and namesake of PageRank, a search ranking algorithm for Google.
importance: Larry Page's contribution to the field of computer science, particularly in the development of widely-used technologies like Google and PageRank, has had significant impacts on how users interact with and locate information online. He also held executive positions in Google and its parent company Alphabet Inc., exerting substantial influence on the company's strategic directions.
politicalInfluence: As co-founders of Google, Page and Brin have profoundly shaped the global technology landscape, influencing policies on privacy, data collection, search engine neutrality, and AI ethics. Their innovations sparked debates and regulations in numerous areas, including antitrust, surveillance, and digital advertising.

name: Sergey Brin
contribution: Co-founded Google with Larry Page. Developed a web search engine which became popular at Stanford, leading to the creation of Google. Developed the PageRank algorithm, a new kind of technology that analyzed the relevance of the backlinks that connected one Web page to another.
importance: Brin's work has revolutionized the field of internet search and digital advertising. Google is one of the most valuable companies in the world and has greatly impacted the way information is accessed online.
politicalInfluence: As co-founders of Google, Page and Brin have profoundly shaped the global technology landscape, influencing policies on privacy, data collection, search engine neutrality, and AI ethics. Their innovations sparked debates and regulations in numerous areas, including antitrust, surveillance, and digital advertising.
